Modern Value Investing book:
https://amzn.to/2lvfH3t

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

Economic trends are going to shape our futures. Also the strength of emerging markets is going to have a huge impact on our investment portfolios. Long term trend investing is essential to achieve good long term returns. 
The world economy is shifting towards Asia and especially China and India. Therefore it is extremely important to be invested in Asia.

Nobody knows where the stock market will go in the short term. However in the long term it is much easier to estimate things because the trends are clear and difficultly disrupted. By positioning your portfolio with positive structural trends as tailwinds you lower the risk of negative surprises and increase the positive ones, especially if you can do it at the same price. The story is recurrent on this channel, emerging markets are the place to invest now and in the next 30 years.
Global businesses are going to operate differently than they operate now.

Investing is most intelligent when most business like. The fact is that when you look at any investments as a business owner and not as a stock price everything is easier. Your focus lies on earnings and not on stock prices. Nobody knows where will stock prices go in the short term but in the long term stock prices follow earnings and business quality. I definitely think that a business like approach is the best possible investing strategy.

Here is the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hAQA_29Htts

The stock market is clearly overvalued from a historical perspective. However, my concern aren't really valuations as much as book values. Book value is the actual value you get and in what should your investment returs be measured, as Buffett prefers to do. The fact is that the return on equity is around 13% while the return on buybacks is around 5% and corporations are paying three times or more the actual value of their business.

snippet.description:

The current S&P 500 yield is around 3%. This is extremely low when compared to the risk that stocks can fall 50% at any point in time. Real estate are far better investments for such low returns as they are much less risky. In the stocks vs. real estate battle, real estate definitely wins on low returns and low risk while stocks win on high returns and relatively low risk. If you can choose, chose real estate in stead of normal stocks now, especially if you can leverage your real estate investment with a 30 year fixed mortgage.

This video is about how to build an all weather portfolio. An all weather portfolio is a very attractive investment. You limit your portfolio risk and receive satisfying investment returns by making all-weather diversification.
In this video I show a practical way how to build an all weather portfolio in this environment with portfolio allocation to stocks, commodity stocks, gold, real estate and treasuries. 
An all weather portfolio performed equally to the S&P 500 in the last 30 years but with much less risk. When inflation, interest rates or economic growth change, the all-weather portfolio will be the way to go. 
I give a few stock ideas for the economic growth part and inflation growth part, discuss treasuries and discuss investments in gold. 
I wonder if Ray Dalio from Bridgewater would be happy with my portfolio structure.

snippet.title: Is Value Investing Dead? 3 Ways to Invest
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

I am also a book author:
Modern Value Investing book:
https://amzn.to/2lvfH3t

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

In every economic and investing cycles value investing is often proclaimed dead. Many describe value investing as obsolete, underperforming but none the less, value investing is still here. All the past fads have died, dot-com bubble, corporate raids of the 1980s, nifty-fifty stocks of the 1970s and many other fads. Value investors underperform for a while in the cycle but over the long term those are the ones remembered as the best investors in a generation. I discuss three options for the current value investor. Staying in cash, emerging markets and turning into a growth investor. Seth Klarman and Warren Buffett both underperformed for longer periods while now they are regarded the best investors out there, even if some again question that as we are in the new bubble.

Is the stock market in a bubble. Well, the definition of a stock market bubble is when stock prices diverge from business fundamentals. As S&P 500 earnings haven't been growing in the past 10 years we are clearly in a bubble. The next question is when will this bubble burst. Well, stock will crash when there will be inflation and central banks won't be able to print money anymore. When will stock prices fall? Nobody knows, but the best thing is to be prepared for a crash.

Palladium is both a precious metal and an industrial metal. It will benefit because it is rare and because demand is high and expected to increase as more cars are being build to satisfy growing automotive global demand. We analyze the demand and supply for palladium, explain the palladium supply deficits, explain the ways to invest in palladium, from palladium stocks, palladium coins and bars to a palladium etf. The stocks are Norilsk Nickel, Sibanye gold and North American palladium. The Palladium ETF is PALL. 
The analysis shows how there is a 50% potential increase in palladium prices in the next few years.

snippet.title: When To Sell Stocks - 5 Strategies Explained
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

I am also a book author:
Modern Value Investing book:
https://amzn.to/2lvfH3t

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

The easiest thing to do is to buy a stock. The difficult thing to do is to know when to sell. Selling stocks is always tricky because a stock can always go up just after you sold it. The first discussed strategy, that looks towards fundamental indicators and uses fundamental analysis certainly helps in avoiding selling too early or too late. Another strategy is portfolio rebalancing that makes things much easier as you have to mechanically sell when something appreciates. The third strategy involves buying something much better, i.e. 50% better than the other portfolio holding. A better investing opportunity can always arise but you shouldn't trade too much around it. The fourth strategy is about using a stop loss. I discuss the pros and cons of using a stop loss. the fifth is not so much a strategy as the reaching of a goal, when you did it, sell your stocks and enjoy your life.

I discuss 10 junior miners stocks, the Van Eck Junior Miners ETF (GDXJ) is also analyzed to see how it is not really a junior gold miner ETF. the things to watch range from net present values,  political risks to gold price moves.

snippet.title: #1 Rule in Investing - It's all about risk reward
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

Positive Asymmetric Risk Reward is what you have to look for in investing and it should be the first rule when investing.
Especially after an 8 year bull market the majority of investors completely forget about risk, nevertheless for long term positive returns it is essential to first think about risk and only afterwards about potential returns. 
In order to improve your investing returns you have to look for investments where the potential loss is much smaller than the potential gain.

Norilsk Nickel is the 2nd largest nickel miner, 1st palladium and 12th copper. Its nickel mining costs are negative while its ore body is high grade and enough for the next 55 years of mining. With expected higher nickel prices, copper supply gap, palladium supply gap Norilsk Nickel presents a high return investment while the low cost make it a margin of safety investment and low risk. The 10% dividend is expected to grow for 27% in 2017. The only issue is that it is a Russian company and many are wary of investing in Russia.

We analyze ECB activity from a long term fundamental perspective and how it affects the structural issues that lead to positive or negative returns in the long term. Especially international investors should not diversify into Europe. European banks are high risk, rates are kept artificially low and the ECB is buying a significant part of GDP, influencing elections and now allowing for companies to go bankrupt. Something similar to what the communist system was doing. 
Investing into European stocks and the euro currency is therefore very risky for the relatively low returns.

In the 2000s everybody was scared by the effect baby boomers retiring will have on the stock market. It has been already 5 years since the first baby boomer retired and stock have been going only up since then. Nevertheless I found an interesting analysis form the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco where they analyze the impact of retiring baby boomers and other age impacts on stock market valuations. The outcome isn't nice at all as the S&P 500 is expected to fall to 920 points in 2025. We will see if it will actually happen but it is a good thing to keep an eye on the risks.

The are three strong trends aligning for an investment in Australia. The population is growing, commodities will recover and interest rates should go up alongside higher inflation. This will make the Australian currency stronger and give an additional return to foreign investors. On top of everything Australian stocks offer high dividends and a stable business environment.
You can buy directly stocks on the Australian stock market, you can buy an Australian ETF, bonds, a currency ETF, but be careful of the Australian dividend withholding tax.
Australia should be an essential part of a well balanced portfolio with international diversification.

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

Modern value investing: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0GWYyxvDP04

Books are essential for investing returns because they allow us to build a better investment mindset. It is not about ratios or financial data, it is all about having a proper financial blueprint. Books give us summarized knowledge from the best investors out there.
The books every investor and trader should read are:
Value investing book : Margin of Safety Seth Klarman - link to my summary: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PXuAoP4M3Mo&list=PLBmr55S1qNIVvhkMCxAWR8v98dkltwzAi&index=1

The Black Swan by Nicholas Nassim Taleb http://amzn.to/2gO7Tu9

Alchemy of Finance George Soros http://amzn.to/2tjWFPO


The Great Investors Greg Arnold http://amzn.to/2uE7kc5

The Intelligent Investor Benjamin Graham http://amzn.to/2gNU7aH

Money Master the Game Anthony Robbins http://amzn.to/2tk8Qfi

Margin of Safety Seth Klarman http://amzn.to/2ufrHvf

Market Wizards Jack D Schwager http://amzn.to/2ue7GDJ

snippet.title: 3 Reasons Stocks Will Go Higher
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

I am also a book author:
Modern Value Investing book:
https://amzn.to/2lvfH3t

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

In economics and financial markets it is simple; it is all about supply and demand. On the stock market that is influenced by liquidity flows. Low interest rates, the FED not winding down its balance sheet and constant flows to passive funds and stock buybacks will push stocks higher, especially the S&P 500, Nasdaq and large caps. 
This will be so until something changes in the mentioned 3 trends. 
I analyze how those trends impact the S&P 500 and its major 5 constituents, apple, Microsoft, jnj, amazon. It is important to understand those factors in order to properly apply an S&P 500 strategy.

snippet.title: Dollar Cost Averaging Investment Strategy Explained
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

I am also a book author:
Modern Value Investing book:
https://amzn.to/2lvfH3t

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

Dollar cost averaging is an investment strategy where you invest a fixed dollar amount per month or year. The benefits are that it is effortless and as shown in the video it limits downside risk, even better, you are happy when stocks drop, and increases the returns, especially when markets are this highly valued. The S&P 500 or other index funds are excellent investments to dollar cost average but also stocks like Berkshire could be an option. 
The sophisticated investor can also apply the DCA investment strategy when considering buying into a falling knife.

Therefore, and investment in China still looks very attractive and is an essential piece of a well balanced portfolio.

Dividends are very important to many investors relying on passive income. If you can own dividend stocks that offer good dividend yields and the potential for passive income growth even better. I have found 10 companies that have relatively high dividends and offer excellent dividend growth prospects for dividend compounding. 
In this economic environment it is very important to look at macroeconomic trends in order to protect your dividend portfolio from inflation, recessions, money printing and various political risks. 
the dividend stocks I found have dividend yields between 3% and 7% and offer the potential to yield 10% to 15% when macroeconomic and business trends change alongside long term currency trends. Also, all companies are exposed to positive demographic trends.

Ray Dalio is one of my favorite investors, his views on the economy are so simple yet so insightful. Most people think short term and that is very dangerous when investing. I summarized Dalio's economic principles and discuss how can one position his portfolio around what will happen in the future economic environment. It is extremely important to expose a portfolio to emerging markets, precious metals, commodities and safe assets.
Ray Dalio was made famous by Anthony Robbins in his books on investing, Unshakeable and Money Master the Game. His all weather portfolio is something to really take a look at especially since it looks that we are close to a change in the economic environment.

snippet.title: 6 Signs of Value Traps in Stocks
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

I am also a book author:
Modern Value Investing book:
https://amzn.to/2lvfH3t

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

A value trap is a stock that looks good because it is cheap and therefore attractive to the value investor. However, it might be cheap for a good reason or many good reasons. Looking at future catalysts, insider activity, analyzing the sector, analyzing the balance sheet, checking the sustainability of the dividend helps in determining whether an investment is a value trap or not, thus lower our investing risks and increase our returns. Investing mistakes can never be avoided but the limiting of them helps in increasing portfolio returns.

You have to be smart when investing in emerging markets and invest when they are cheap and on the verge of an economic turnaround. The large majority of international investors does the opposite, they invest in euphoria and lose money. Brazilian stocks are relatively cheap and the positive economic environment will be a tailwind. Some are more expensive, like AmBev, while others are relatively cheap, like Brazilian banks and Brazilian utilities. The Brazilian currency could turnaround with the economy and add an additional benefit to your international portfolio diversification. And, there are better options to invest in Brazil than a Brazil ETF which is overweight financials.

snippet.title: Investing? Watch what the FED, European Central bank and Bank of Japan are doing!
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

I am also a book author:
Modern Value Investing book:
https://amzn.to/2lvfH3t

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

Financial markets are distorted by Central Bank activity. $21 trillion makes a third of the global bond market and a quarter of the stock market. This makes Central banks a very significant player. 

I have read the FED's and ECB's meeting minutes, give a summary and discuss potential scenarios and how to be prepared. The situation has no historical precedents, therefore it has to be closely watched, whether you are a saver, bond holder, mutual fund investor or stock investor. A few things can happen and the best thing is to be prepared! If things go well, the FED is going to hike rates which won't be good for stocks and bonds. If a recession hits the economy, much more money printing will occur.

snippet.title: Chinese stocks analysis #1 ZTO Express - Fairly priced growth stock
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

I will analyze the 16 Chinese stocks I find most interesting from a risk reward perspective. ZTO Express (NYSE: ZTO) is a Chinese package delivery company growing at around 30% per year. Price earnings ratio is 33 while the company has no long term debt and enough cash from the IPO to finance its growth. This China stock looks like a very interesting growth pick for a well balanced emerging market portfolio.

snippet.title: CAPE ratio - Cyclically Adjusted Price Earnings Ratio
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

I am also a book author:
Modern Value Investing book:
https://amzn.to/2lvfH3t

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

The Cyclically Adjusted Price Earnings Ratio is an excellent measure of long term earnings quality and stock price undervaluation or overvaluation. Used also by Benjamin Graham, later promoted and made academic by Shiller, that won a Nobel prize, the CAPE has shown many times over that it really works over the long time. Excellent for analyzing sectors, indexes, countries and long term stock analysis.
The is also the Barclays Shiller Cape ETN that has performed well by rebalancing across sectors through using the CAPE.

However, I'll elaborate on a stock, Berkshire Hathaway, that is less risky than the S&P 500 because it is better diversified, it is growth oriented and doesn't do shareholder value destroying buybacks and has had and will have better future returns. 

Those who promote index funds are doing a disservice to the community. Warren Buffett must promote them because if he would do otherwise the S&P 500 would terribly fall and the economy would enter into a recession.

Investing in oil stocks for the longer term with a margin of safety depends totally on demand, supply and production costs. I discuss Exxon's plans, how much the major oil producers are investing, what are their breakeven oil production costs and how can an investor go about it.

With oil prices above $50 per barrel it is risky to invest as most producers look at projects that are profitable below $40. Given that there is plenty of oil, it is extremely important to look at what will future production costs be.

1:38 Invest, don't speculate
3.29 Don't pay fees to Wall Street
4:20 Where are the customers' yachts?
4:52 Value investing is the best
6:56 Buy at bargain prices
7:38 Be patient, opportunities will come
8:42 Believe the market is inefficient
9:26 Always have a cash cushion
10:24 Don't be afraid to average down
12:43 Trade to rebalance
13:17 Know what you are doing

snippet.title: Invest like Gary Vaynerchuk
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

I am also a book author:
Modern Value Investing book:
https://amzn.to/2lvfH3t

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

Not everybody has the connections, the knowledge and the money to invest like Gary Vaynerchuk. However, you can follow a similar strategy by investing in social media companies on the stock market. You won't make as much but the risk reward is similar. This is, you will lose everything on some investments but gain hugely on others.

snippet.title: Temporal diversification - diversify like Warren Buffett does
snippet.description:
What do I do? Full-time independent stock market analyst and researcher:
https://sven-carlin-research-platform.teachable.com/p/stock-market-research-platform

Check the comparative stock list table on my Stock market research platform under curriculum preview!

I am also a book author:
Modern Value Investing book:
https://amzn.to/2lvfH3t

More about me and some written reports at the Sven Carlin blog: https://svencarlin.com

Stock market for modern value investors Facebook Group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/modernvalueinvesting/

Buffett doesn't buy a bit of everything, he buys a lot of one stock when the specific stock is cheap. He bought AAPL below $120, airlines at single digit valuations, Coca-Cola after dropping 30% etc. Temporal diversification can lead to dividend yields of above 100% over the long term.
